text: Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For symptoms of nasal blockage type, use a combination of leukotriene receptor antagonists or prostaglandin D2/thromboxane A2 receptor antagonist and nasal topical steroids. For symptoms of combined type, add second-generation antihistamine.

Patients with liver hemangioma @ For hepatic hemangiomas accompanied by dysfunction in other vital organs and deemed unsuitable for surgical resection, treatment options include percutaneous RFA for hepatic hemangiomas, as well as open surgical RFA for hepatic hemangiomas.
triples: open surgical RFA for hepatic hemangiomas

text: Patients with recurrent respiratory tract infections @ In cases of viral infection with persistent high fever, consideration may be given to the combined use of Xiyenping or Heduning for treatment.
triples: Patients with recurrent respiratory tract infections
Patients with recurrent respiratory tract infections
Patients with recurrent respiratory tract infections
Patients with recurrent respiratory tract infections

text: Patients with liver cancer @ For patients with poor liver reserve function, unstable hemodynamics, and no surgical conditions, Transarterial Embolization can be considered.
Patients with HCV @ Patients with HIV/HCV co-infection should undergo HCV treatment, and antiretroviral therapy for HIV is also recommended.
Patients with sclerosing cholangitis @ Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) can be performed as rescue TIPS in patients with refractory/uncontrollable variceal bleeding.
Patients with CKD @ For CKD patients with HCV infection who have been treated with interferon, it is recommended to use sofosbuvir/velpatasvir.
Patients with DVT @ Upon symptom relief, maintain the original dose or half dose of PPI once daily. In case of recurrent symptoms, consider escalating to the full dose of PPI for maintenance.

Patients with breast cancer @ For patients at high risk of recurrence (such as lymph node positive), dual targeted therapy (trastuzumab and pertuzumab) combined with adjuvant chemotherapy is recommended. Pertuzumab is administered once every 3 weeks at a dose of 420 mg for 1 year.

Patients with WD @ For patients with Wilson's disease who have failed to respond or are intolerant to medical treatment and have progressed to advanced chronic liver disease, liver transplantation should be considered as soon as possible.
triples: failed to respond to medical treatment

text: Patients with liver cancer @ For patients with hepatic vein or vena cava tumor thrombus, complete hepatic vascular occlusion can be performed to remove the tumor thrombus as a whole whenever possible.
triples: remove the tumor thrombus as a whole

text: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy patients @ Treatment of acute hypotension with inotropes may be harmful in obstructive patients. Digoxin should be avoided in patients with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.
Patients with NSCLC @ SBRT is recommended for patients with severe comorbidities, advanced age, and those who refuse surgery.
Patients with candidiasis @ An echinocandin is preferred for patients who have had recent azole exposure, whose illness is moderately severe or severe.

Patients with acute-on-chronic liver failure @ Parenteral feeding should be considered in patients who cannot meet their nutritional needs using the gastrointestinal tract or in those with an unprotected airway, such as in patients with grade 3-4 HE.
triples: cannot meet their nutritional needs using the gastrointestinal tract

text: CBP and CP/CPPS patients @ If you have adverse side effects to a-adrenergic antagonists, consider offering uroselective a-adrenergic antagonists (e.g. tamsulosin, alfuzosin and silodosin) as first-line treatment in patients with CBP and CP/CPPS who present with voiding LUTS (Level 5).
triples: adverse side effects to a-adrenergic antagonists

text: Patients with liver cancer @ For patients with portal vein tumor thrombus, temporarily blocking the blood flow in the healthy portal vein should be considered during the portal vein thrombectomy to prevent the spread of the tumor thrombus.
triples: temporarily blocking the blood flow in the healthy portal vein

text: Patients with pheochromocytomas @ All pheochromocytomas have a potential for malignant transformation. If surgery is feasible, it is mandatory for all cases. In patients with inoperable pheochromocytomas, treatment options may include 131I-MIBG, 177Lu-Dotatate, and other therapeutic approaches.
Patients with autoimmune hepatitis @ For patients with poor adherence to treatment or severe clinical symptoms, a liver biopsy should be considered prior to treatment withdrawal.

Patients with sclerosing cholangitis @ For mild attacks, a common first-line agent is an ampicillin/beta-lactamase inhibitors since these agents can be administered orally. More severe cases are treated with intravenous antibiotics with piperacillin/ tazobactam.
Patients with NSCLC @ Those with local symptoms or brain metastases are recommended to combine radiotherapy or other treatments based on chemotherapy.

Patients with gastrolithiasis @ Patients with mild symptoms may use medications such as cola and fibrinolytic enzymes for chemical dissolution. Fibrinolytic enzyme 3-5g, for a total of 2-5 days. For patients with moderate to severe symptoms, endoscopic removal is required.

Mitral valve prolapse patients @ Most patients with mitral valve prolapse do not require treatment. If there is tachycardia, β-blockers can be used to slow down the heart rate, thereby relieving symptoms such as palpitations.
Adults with hypothyroidism @ For young or elderly patients, as well as those with a history of coronary artery disease or arrhythmias, a lower dose of L-T3 is recommended.

Patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease @ We suggest consideration of transoral incisionless fundoplication (TIF) for patients with troublesome regurgitation or heartburn who do not wish to undergo antireflux surgery and who do not have severe reflux esophagitis or hiatal hernias >2 cm. (Conditional recommendation, low level of evidence)
triples: do not wish to undergo antireflux surgery
do not have severe reflux esophagitis

text: Patients with viral hepatitis @ In those with renal dysfunction, ETV or TAF are  preferred.

Patients with vaginal laxity syndrome @ If a patient lacks columnar folds and does not have specific defects in a particular area, for those with a widened mid-vagina, G-spot amplification may be considered to reduce the width of the mid-vagina.

Patients with cirrhosis @ For patients without esophageal varices detected during initial screening, repeat endoscopy every 2-3 years is recommended. For compensated cirrhotic patients with mild esophageal varices identified during initial screening, repeat endoscopy every 1-2 years is advised. For decompensated cirrhotic patients in whom esophageal varices have essentially disappeared after treatment, repeat endoscopy every 6-12 months is recommended.
triples: without esophageal varices detected during initial screening

text: Patients with cirrhosis @ For patients undergoing invasive treatment for hepatocellular carcinoma or esophagogastric varices, dietary/nutritional therapy is strongly recommended to improve protein-energy malnutrition.
triples: undergoing invasive treatment for hepatocellular carcinoma
undergoing invasive treatment for esophagogastric varices

text: Patients with primary biliary cholangitis @ For those with portal hypertension, upper gastrointestinal endoscopy can be performed in the second trimester.
Patients with NSCLC @ Sequential durvalumab treatment for 1 year can be considered for patients with unresectable stage III NSCLC if there is no disease progression after concurrent chemoradiation.
triples: there is no disease progression after concurrent chemoradiation.

text: Patient with gastric cancer @ For patients with metastatic/recurrent disease, comprehensive treatment based on drug therapy is recommended.
Patients with keloid @ For patients with extremely large keloids, if the patient is elderly or not suitable for extensive surgery, a staged excision approach may be a preferable surgical method.

Sleep apnea patients @ Continuous positive airway pressure therapy is beneficial for improving sleep quality and daytime sleepiness in patients with obstructive sleep apnea accompanied by cardiovascular disease.

Patients with hepatitis C @ The recommended dosage for children aged 3 and above, with a body weight less than 17kg, is 150mg/37.5mg of sofosbuvir/velpatasvir per day. For children with a body weight between 17-30kg, the recommended dosage is 200mg/50mg per day. For children with a body weight of 30kg or more, the recommended dosage is 400mg/100mg per day.
triples: with a body weight less than 17kg

text: Patients with PHP @ For pregnant and lactating patients with PHP, it is recommended to use active vitamin D and its analogs in combination with calcium supplements to maintain blood calcium levels.
triples: active vitamin D and its analogs

text: Patients with familial adenomatous polyps @ If the new polyps appear too quickly or grow excessively, rectal resection and the creation of a permanent colostomy may be necessary.
triples: the new polyps appear too quickly
rectal resection and the creation of a permanent colostomy

text: Patients with keloid @ For scars on the ear, the primary treatment approach remains surgical excision in principle.
Patients with OSA @ Upper airway surgery is suitable for OSA patients with upper airway obstruction.

Infantile cholestasis @ In cases of chronic intrahepatic cholestasis in children with poor response to internal medicine treatment, clinical symptom relief may be achieved through biliary diversion procedures.
triples: poor response to internal medicine treatment

text: Patients with AP @ For patients with fecal elastase 1 <100 mcg/gm or patients with typical manifestations of steatorrhea, pancreatic enzyme supplementation and replacement therapy should be given.
triples: pancreatic enzyme supplementation and replacement therapy

text: Patients with keloid @ For scar types characterized by pronounced congestion, rapid infiltration into the surrounding area, anti-inflammatory drug injection therapy (such as corticosteroids) is often effective. However, for types of scars with less obvious congestion, dark color, prominent surface, and rapid growth resembling a "tumor," a treatment strategy primarily focused on surgical intervention is preferable.
triples: rapid infiltration into the surrounding area

text: Elderly patients with osteoporosis @ Parathyroid hormone analogues may be used in patients at high risk for vertebral fractures or at high risk for nonvertebral fractures who do not respond well to bone resorption inhibitors.
triples: at high risk for vertebral fractures
at high risk for nonvertebral fractures
not respond well to bone resorption inhibitors.

text: Patients with Hereditary hemochromatosis @ We therefore recommend the use of iron chelation for the treatment of HH for the patient who is intolerant or refractory to phlebotomy or when phlebotomy has the potential for harm.

Patients with rheumatoid arthritis @ For patients with poor response or poor tolerance to methotrexate, if patients have adverse prognostic factors, add-on biologic therapy may be considered (TNFa antagonist, abatacept, tocilizumab or, in specific situations, rituximab). If patients do not have adverse prognostic factors, the recommended treatment is either combined synthetic DMARD therapy (e.g., methotrexate + sulfasalazine + hydroxychloroquine).
Patients with MMA and PA @ For patients with functional amenorrhea hormone replacement therapy or hormonal contraceptives should be offered.

Patients with simple hallux valgus @ For middle-aged to elderly patients with severe hallux valgus angle (HVA) enlargement, especially those with metatarsus adductus, correcting the deformity may involve first metatarsophalangeal joint fusion.

Patients with HCV-GN @ For HCV-associated glomerulonephritis patients with severe cryoglobulinemia or rapidly progressing renal failure, it is recommended to use DAA treatment along with immunosuppressive agents and/or plasma exchange therapy.
Patients with Sjögren's Disease @ Sjögren's Disease @ Chlorhexidine administered by varnish, gel, or rinse may be considered in SD patients with dry mouth and a high root caries rate.

Hypoparathyroidism patients @ Patients with symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia, such as hand and foot cramps, should receive active intravenous calcium supplementation. Administer 10-20 mL of 10% calcium gluconate slowly by intravenous infusion.
Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For mild symptoms, administer second-generation antihistamine or a mast cell stabilizer. If symptoms are exacerbated, concomitantly use nasal topical steroids early.
Patients with NSCLC @ For patients with resistance to EGFR-TKI or ALK inhibitor in the first line, platinum-doublet or monotherapy regimen can be selected.

Patients with SAP @ For SAP patients with concomitant acute kidney injury, the choice between continuous slow and low-efficiency hemodialysis or continuous renal replacement therapy may be made based on hemodynamic status.
Patients with oral lichen planus @ Hydroxychloroquine sulfate is effective in the treatment of persistent erosive lesions. The recommended oral dose is 200 to 400mg per day.

Patients with hepatitis B @ For patients who have not undergone Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy and do not require HAART treatment in the near future, non-HIV-active drugs should be chosen for antiviral treatment against HBV.
triples: do not require HAART treatment in the near future
have not undergone Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy

text: Patients with oral lichen planus @ For patients with severe local damage, topical application of corticosteroid cream is an option, and for those with extensive erosion, a corticosteroid solution can be used as a mouthwash.

CBP and CP/CPPS patients @ For patients who are refractory to treatment, if there is any trauma (including physical, emotional, or sexual abuse;), an MDT approach is recommended that integrates medication, physical therapy, and psychotherapy into the patient-specific of individualized holistic treatment plans.

Patients with liver cancer @ For single tumors with a diameter of 3 to 7 cm or multiple tumors that are not suitable for surgical resection, combination therapy with transarterial TACE can be considered.
triples: single tumors with a diameter of 3 to 7 cm

text: Patient with gastric cancer @ For tumors located in the lower part of the stomach, distal gastrectomy or total gastrectomy may be considered, while total gastrectomy may be performed for carcinoma located in the corpus. For adenocarcinoma located on the proximal side of EGJ, proximal gastrectomy or total gastrectomy should be taken into consideration.
triples: tumors located in the lower part of the stomach
adenocarcinoma located on the proximal side of EGJ

text: Patients with NSCLC @ Topotecan, irinotecan, gemcitabine, vinorelbine, temozolomide, or paclitaxel is recommended for patients with recurrence within 6 months after first-line chemotherapy.
triples: recurrence within 6 months after first-line chemotherapy

text: Patients with liver cancer @ For symptomatic bone metastasis patients, bisphosphonates can be used.

Patients with candidiasis @ For patients with normal renal function, oral fluorocytosine therapy is usually administered at a dose of 25mg/kg, four times a day.. Dose adjustment is necessary for patients with renal dysfunction.

Patients with pancreatic cancer @ Patients with moderate to severe pain should receive an adequate dose of oral opioid medications to alleviate pain. For chronic pain, long-acting formulations such as transdermal fentanyl, hydrocodone, and hydromorphone are often preferred.

Patients with WD @ For asymptomatic infants, zinc supplementation may commence at the age of 2 to 3 years. In the case of asymptomatic Wilson's disease (WD) identified in young individuals, zinc supplementation or D-penicillamine copper-chelating therapy may be initiated early on a low-copper diet.

Patients with main pancreatic duct obstruction @ For small-sized main pancreatic duct stones, successful drainage can be achieved through endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). For main pancreatic duct stones larger than 5 mm, extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is the preferred treatment.
triples: Patients with main pancreatic duct obstruction
Patients with main pancreatic duct obstruction
Patients with main pancreatic duct obstruction
Patients with main pancreatic duct obstruction
main pancreatic duct stones larger than 5 mm
Patients with main pancreatic duct obstruction

text: Patients with COPD @ For low-risk patients experiencing AECOPD, inhalation bronchodilators are recommended as the initial treatment. For high-risk AECOPD patients, a combination therapy including Inhaled Corticosteroids is recommended.

Patients with AI @ For patients with initial assessments indicating benign characteristics and a maximum diameter of less than 3 cm in adrenal incidentalomas (AI), frequent imaging examinations (such as CT scans) are not recommended. Instead, follow-up every 1 to 2 years is sufficient. In patients with an initial negative hormone assessment for AI, repeated hormone testing is not advisable.
triples: maximum diameter of less than 3 cm
frequent imaging examinations are not recommended
repeated hormone testing is not advisable

text: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease @ In patients where nutritional requirements cannot be met, enteral nutrition or parenteral nutrition is indicated.

Patients with DILI @ Cases with good treatment responsiveness to corticosteroids in the initial treatment respond well to an increased dose or resuming steroid therapy when a relapse occurs. For recurrent relapses, adding or switching to AZA 1-2 mg/kg/day should be considered.
triples: Cases with good treatment responsiveness to corticosteroids

text: Patients with pancreatic cancer @ For patients with resectable localized pancreatic cancer who cannot tolerate or refuse surgery, radical precision radiotherapy is recommended.

Patients with MMA and PA @ L-Dopa/Carbidopa, trihexylphenidyl, clonazepam, baclofen (oral, continuous intrathecal, ventriculoperitoneal shunt) treatments can be effective in patients with acute/chronic dyskinesia and movement disorder.

Patients with liver damage @ For choreiform movements and bradykinesia, medications such as clonazepam and flupenthixol may be considered. In cases of agitation or mania, options include quetiapine, olanzapine, risperidone, and chlorpromazine. For individuals with apathy or depression, antidepressant medications may be appropriate.
Patients with liver cancer @ For patients with resectable liver tumors, good liver reserve function, and stable hemodynamics, surgical resection is the preferred option.

Patients with AI @ For patients with unilateral AI diagnosed with ACS, if metabolic abnormalities such as hypertension, diabetes, or osteoporosis related to cortisol excess are present, laparoscopic resection of the tumor on the affected side is recommended. In the case of bilateral AI with diagnosed ACS, it is advisable to perform adrenal vein sampling (AVS) to determine the dominant side of cortisol secretion before considering unilateral adrenalectomy or bilateral adrenalectomy.
triples: laparoscopic resection of the tumor on the affected side

text: Patients with OMM @ Early cryotherapy or surgical excision is recommended for suspected mucosal nevi or pigmented lesions.
Patients with hallux valgus @ For elderly patients with severe thumb arthritis and significant deformity, the preferred treatment may be first metatarsophalangeal joint fusion.
Patients with allergic rhinitis @ For cases with severe nasal blockage, treatment may be started with oral corticosteroid administration for 4-7 days.

Patients with primary liver cancer @ For patients with CNLC stage IIIa liver cancer, surgery is generally not the preferred initial option. However, if there is involvement of the hepatic vein but the lesions are confined within the liver, surgical resection can be considered.
triples: involvement of the hepatic vein but the lesions are confined within the liver
surgery is generally not the preferred initial option

text: Patients with hyperglycemia @ For critically ill patients with DKA or hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state, as well as those with altered mental status, continuous intravenous infusion of insulin is recommended.
Patients with acute cholecystitis @ Patients who are not suitable for surgery, but who are septic due to gallbladder empyema, are effectively treated by PTGBD.
Elderly patients with chronic bronchitis @ For patients with glaucoma, Kebiqing should not be used; for patients with gastric ulcer, potassium iodide and ammonium chloride should not be used.

Patients with adrenal accidental tumor @ In cases of adrenal incidentaloma with radiological features indicative of malignancy or hormonal secretion abnormalities, surgical intervention is often warranted.
Patients with achalasia @ We suggest that peroral endoscopic myotomy is a safe option in patients with achalasia who have previously undergone pneumatic dilation or laparoscopic Heller myotomy.

Patients with mitral regurgitation @ For mild mitral valve regurgitation, no specific treatment is necessary. If more severe regurgitation leads to heart failure but the patient cannot undergo surgery, certain heart failure medications such as sacubitril, spironolactone, and carvedilol may be administered.
Patients with iron deficiency anemia @ When oral iron therapy is ineffective, consider using intravenous iron supplementation to treat iron deficiency anemia.
Patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease @ For patients with nocturnal GERD symptoms, we recommend elevating the head of the bed.
triples: elevating the head of the bed

text: Patients with NSCLC @ For patients with negative driver genes, platinum-doublet regimens are the standard first-line chemotherapy regimen.
Patients with PSC @ People with PSC and intense and frequent bacterial cholangitis may in severe cases be considered for permanent rotating antibiotics up to time of transplantation.

rheumatic fever patients @ For patients with chorea, valproic acid is the first choice. Patients with ineffective valproic acid or severe chorea such as paralysis should be treated with carbamazepine.

Patients with stress ulcer @ For severe patients, it is recommended to use standard dose intravenous infusion of PPI, once every 12 hours, for at least 3 consecutive days. When the patient is stable and tolerates enteral nutrition or has eaten, the patient can be switched to oral medications or gradually discontinued.
Patients with DME @ For patients with central macular edema (DME) and impaired vision, anti VEGF injection therapy should be considered, and immediate or delayed focused laser therapy can be chosen.
Patients with iron deficiency anemia @ For patients with mild anemia, oral iron supplements can be used to supplement.

Patient with gastric cancer @ For patients who cannot be resected due to poor physical condition or basic diseases, conversion therapy is not applicable, palliative chemotherapy and radiotherapy can be considered.

Patients with primary biliary cholangitis @ Timely liver biopsies are recommended for cholestatic patients with unknown causes and negative PBC antibodies to confirm the diagnosis and avoid delayed treatment.

Patients with keloid @ For children aged 12 and below with keloids, if non-surgical treatment results in relief of symptoms and improvement of the condition, continued treatment to maintain long-term prevention of scarring is appropriate. If treatment proves ineffective, consideration may be given to adjunctive therapies such as laser treatment, cryotherapy, along with silicone preparations and compression therapy.
Patients with cirrhosis @ In cases of moderate or greater severity, the stan dard is ≥ 0.8 mg/kg/day. Otherwise, PSL is initiated at doses of ≥0.6 mg/kg/day.
Patients with malignant pleural effusion @ For patients with frail constitution and in the terminal stage, repeated therapeutic thoracentesis may provide temporary relief from respiratory distress.

Patients with keloid @ For patients with medium to large keloids, if there is no history of prior treatment, a comprehensive approach primarily involving surgical treatment is recommended. For those with a history of prior treatment and recurrence, a combined therapeutic strategy involving radiation and chemotherapy may be considered.
triples: a history of prior treatment and recurrence

text: Patients with hypocalcemia @ For patients with hypocalcemia due to calcium-sensing receptor inactivity mutations, magnesium supplements are often necessary due to excessive urinary magnesium loss.

Patients with NSCLC @ For partial stage IA NSCLC patients with advanced age or low lung function, anatomical segmental or wedge resection plus systemic hilar or mediastinal lymph node dissection or sampling should be considered.
